context: The GC analysis performed not only identified β-ocimene, but also provided good resolution of the peaks corresponding to the E and Z stereoisomeric forms. (E)-β-ocimene was detected in both control and treated plants, with a maximum emission from the inoculated plants after 72 h; in contrast, the (Z)-β-ocimene isomer was present only starting from 24 h after inoculation in the treated plants (Fig. 1). However, the maximum percentage of (Z)-β-ocimene was seen after 2 days. As previously reported, (E)-β-ocimene is a commonly emitted compound, and recent studies demonstrated that infected plants can also emit (E)-β-ocimene, as showed in Cucumber Mosaic Virus-Cucurbita pepo interaction. To our knowledge, other isomers of ocimene are under investigations for their roles on inducing a subset of stress related genes in Arabidopsis plants. The infection of these tobacco plants with G. cichoracearum caused a moderate increased emission of MeSA, as compared with control plants (Fig. 1). It is already well documented that resistance against biotrophic pathogens is generally associated with activation of the SA pathway.

llm_generation.summary: (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene, specifically in the form of (E)-β-ocimene, is mentioned in the context of plant responses to infection and stress, but there is no direct discussion of drug interactions. The focus is on the emission of this compound from treated plants and its potential role in stress-related gene activation. While drug interactions may be relevant in a broader context, they are not specifically addressed in relation to (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene in this study.
